children.step: Gather Ingredients
Determine Recipe Requirements

Initiate Visual Scan: Activate optical sensors. Focus primary lens on digital recipe document (PDF file ‘ChocolateChipCookieRecipe.pdf’). Zoom lens adjustment to 3x magnification. Verify image clarity at 150 pixels per degree resolution.
Ingredient Identification: Locate ‘Butter’ entry. Using laser rangefinder

Ingredient Quantity Measurement: Extend robotic arm. Deploy measuring spoon (stainless steel, 1/2 cup capacity). Slowly lower spoon to the ‘Butter’ entry. Align spoon’s open end with the bottom edge of the ‘Butter’ text. Activate tactile sensor on spoon’s bottom. Record spoon position as ‘Butter_Position’. Record spoon angle relative to document surface: Angle = 3.14 radians (180 degrees).

Ingredient Volume Capture: Deploy integrated volume sensor. Calibrate sensor to Spoon Volume (1/2 cup). Execute volume capture sequence. Record volume captured as ‘Butter_Volume’ in milliliters (148 ml). Trigger audio confirmation signal: ‘VolumeCaptured_Butter’.

Ingredient Identification: Locate ‘Granulated Sugar’ entry. Repeat measurement steps from ‘Butter’ identification. Record ‘Sugar_X’, ‘Sugar_Y’, and ‘Sugar_Z’ coordinates. Verify image clarity at 150 pixels per degree resolution.

Ingredient Volume Capture: Deploy measuring spoon (stainless steel, 1 cup capacity). Slowly lower spoon to the ‘Granulated Sugar’ entry. Align spoon’s open end with the bottom edge of the ‘Granulated Sugar’ text. Activate tactile sensor on spoon’s bottom. Record spoon position as ‘Sugar_Position’. Record spoon angle relative to document surface: Angle = 3.14 radians (180 degrees).

Ingredient Volume Capture: Deploy integrated volume sensor. Calibrate sensor to Spoon Volume (1 cup). Execute volume capture sequence. Record volume captured as ‘Sugar_Volume’ in milliliters (237 ml). Trigger audio confirmation signal: ‘VolumeCaptured_Sugar’.

Ingredient Identification: Locate ‘Chocolate Chips’ entry. Repeat measurement steps from ‘Butter’ identification. Record ‘Chips_X’, ‘Chips_Y’, and ‘Chips_Z’ coordinates. Verify image clarity at 150 pixels per degree resolution.

Ingredient Volume Capture: Deploy measuring spoon (stainless steel, 1 cup capacity). Slowly lower spoon to the ‘Chocolate Chips’ entry. Align spoon’s open end with the bottom edge of the ‘Chocolate Chips’ text. Activate tactile sensor on spoon’s bottom. Record spoon position as ‘Chips_Position’. Record spoon angle relative to document surface: Angle = 3.14 radians (180 degrees).

Ingredient Volume Capture: Deploy integrated volume sensor. Calibrate sensor to Spoon Volume (1 cup). Execute volume capture sequence. Record volume captured as ‘Chips_Volume’ in milliliters (237 ml). Trigger audio confirmation signal: ‘VolumeCaptured_Chips’.

Data Consolidation: Transfer all recorded volumes – ‘Butter_Volume’, ‘Sugar_Volume’, ‘Chips_Volume’ – to central database. Verify database integrity. Output report: ‘RecipeRequirementsReport.txt’ containing all ingredient volumes.
Check Existing Pantry Stock

Initiate optical scanning sequence. Activate high-resolution camera module. Calibration target (white square, 10cm x 10cm) must be centered within the camera's field of view. Stabilize camera platform on a level surface. Maintain steady platform position for 3.5 seconds.

Execute image processing algorithm: Identify all objects within a 1.8-meter radius. Prioritize object detection based on size - objects larger than 20cm receive highest priority. Record object coordinates (X, Y, Z) with precision +/- 1mm. Minimum of 3 object detections required to proceed.

For each detected object, initiate object classification protocol. Analyze object color spectrum with a wavelength range of 400-700nm.  Record color data as RGB values (Red, Green, Blue) with a precision of +/- 0.01 for each channel.  Store color data alongside object coordinates.

Compare recorded color data against a pre-defined database of food items. Database contains RGB color values for 100 common pantry items (e.g., ‘Canned Tomatoes’, ‘Pasta’, ‘Rice’).  Match algorithm must achieve a color similarity score of 85% or higher for a successful identification. Threshold value adjustable +/- 2%.

If a match is found (color similarity score >= 85%), record the item name and its identified location (X, Y, Z coordinates) in the central database.  Update inventory count by incrementing the corresponding item's quantity by one.  Log timestamp of the update.

If no match is found after 5 seconds of scanning, proceed to the next detected object.  If no objects are detected within the scanning radius for 60 seconds, terminate scanning sequence and report ‘No items found’ to central command.

Repeat steps 3-6 for each detected object within the pantry area. Maintain a log of all scanned items and their locations. Scan radius: 1.8 meters.  Scanning time per object: Maximum 10 seconds.  Pause between object scans: 1 second.

Upon completion of the scanning sequence, perform a final system diagnostic check. Verify camera calibration, sensor readings, and database synchronization. Report status: ‘Pantry Stock Check Complete’ or ‘Error: [Error Code]’.
Create a Shopping List

Initialize Robotic Arm: Activate designated robotic arm (Unit 734) and confirm operational status. Verify joint angles are within nominal ranges: Shoulder Roll - 0.0 degrees, Elbow Flexion - -15.0 degrees, Wrist Rotation - 2.5 degrees.  Calibration sequence initiated, duration: 5 seconds.

Access Digital Shopping List Database: Execute command ‘Retrieve Shopping List’ (SL-2023-10-27-01). Confirm data transfer completion.  Verify list length: 12 items.  Data received at 1.2 MB/s.  Transfer duration: 3.1 seconds.

Locate Designated Output Tray: Move Robotic Arm to pre-defined coordinates (X: 1.5 meters, Y: 0.7 meters, Z: 0.3 meters). Confirm alignment with output tray (ID: OT-42).  Distance verification using laser rangefinder – accuracy: +/- 0.01 meters.

Item 1: Apple - Record Data:  Extend Robotic Arm wrist by 10.0 centimeters.  Activate spray nozzle.  Apply 0.5 milliliters of clear, non-toxic coating to the surface of the output tray.  Retrieve pre-printed label (ID: L-APPLE-01).  Position label 5.0 centimeters above the output tray.  Initiate label application sequence – duration: 0.8 seconds.  Confirm label placement at X: 0.2 meters, Y: 0.1 meters, Z: 0.0 meters.  Maintain pressure of 1.5 Newtons for 0.3 seconds.

Repeat Item 1 Process: Execute steps from previous item for each of the 12 items on the shopping list. Ensure identical positioning and pressure application for each item.  Track each item's data using internal timestamp and sensor readings.

Verification Scan: Activate integrated 3D scanner. Perform complete scan of the output tray contents.  Analyze scan data for spatial consistency and object recognition.  Generate verification report – duration: 12 seconds.  Report stored locally as ‘VerificationReport_ShoppingList_20231027.txt’.

Tray Retrieval: Execute command ‘Retrieve Output Tray’. Move robotic arm to designated collection area (X: 2.8 meters, Y: 1.9 meters, Z: 0.5 meters). Confirm tray placement on collection platform.  Platform pressure sensor – confirmation of weight: 2.3 kilograms.

System Shutdown: Execute command ‘Shutdown Unit 734’.  Deactivate robotic arm.  Power down all auxiliary systems.  Verification of power loss: Confirm no active motor currents above 0.1 Amp for 5 seconds.
Go to Grocery Store

Initiate Navigation Protocol: Engage GPS module. Verify current location coordinates: Latitude 34.0522, Longitude -118.2437. Confirm destination coordinates: Latitude 34.0740, Longitude -118.2437. Activate pedestrian navigation mode. Set target speed: 3.5 km/h.

Execute Initial Forward Movement: Extend right robotic arm 0.3 meters. Initiate forward movement. Maintain speed: 3.5 km/h. Monitor sidewalk detection sensor. Upon detection of sidewalk, reduce speed to 1.5 km/h. Continue forward movement for 5.2 meters.

Sidewalk Lane Change (Left): Monitor pedestrian traffic flow ahead. When pedestrian traffic density exceeds 1 person per 2 meters, activate turn signal (left). Execute a 90-degree counter-clockwise turn. Maintain speed: 2.0 km/h. Rotate arm 15 degrees to the left. Continue forward movement for 3.1 meters.

Approach Grocery Store: Utilize visual sensor array to identify Grocery Store entrance. Calculate distance to entrance: 12.5 meters. Increase speed to 4.0 km/h. Upon reaching 7.5 meters, activate proximity alert. Maintain speed: 4.0 km/h. Upon reaching the entrance, decelerate to 0.8 km/h.

Enter Store: Extend right robotic arm 0.5 meters. Step forward into the store entrance. Utilize pressure sensors to confirm stable footing. Adjust gait to 1.0 m/s. Maintain orientation relative to store entrance. Scan surrounding area for marked checkout lanes using color and size recognition algorithms.

Navigate to Checkout Lane 3: Based on visual sensor data, calculate the shortest path to Checkout Lane 3. Distance to lane: 8.2 meters. Adjust gait to 1.1 m/s. Rotate arm 10 degrees to the left.  Monitor crowd density via visual sensors, adjusting speed as needed to maintain a safe distance of 1.5 meters from surrounding pedestrians. Upon reaching the lane, stop 0.7 meters short of the lane entrance.

Checkout Interaction (Simulated): Extend right robotic arm 0.2 meters towards the checkout operator.  Maintain a fixed, neutral posture.  Simulate transaction based on pre-programmed data.  Terminate interaction upon completion of simulated transaction.  Retract right robotic arm 0.3 meters.
Exit Store: Repeat steps from Entering the Store, but proceed towards the store exit.  Navigate to the store exit. Exit the store and return to original location coordinates.
Select Ingredients Based on List

Initialize Robotic Arm Position: Move Robotic Arm Joint 1 to an X-axis coordinate of 0.0 meters, Joint 2 to 0.0 meters, Joint 3 to 0.0 meters. Maintain a stable posture with a 90-degree angle at all three joints for 0.5 seconds to establish a baseline.

Retrieve Ingredient List: Activate Optical Scanner. Scan the digital list of ingredients (provided as a 2D barcode image). Confirm barcode integrity with a confidence level of 95% or higher. Store list data in internal memory slot A.

Locate Ingredient 1 – Canned Tomatoes (14.5 oz): Using the stored list data, navigate Robotic Arm to Shelf 3, Level 2. Extend Robotic Arm Joint 1 to a position 0.3 meters above the floor. Adjust Joint 2 and Joint 3 until the optical sensor identifies 'Canned Tomatoes (14.5 oz)' with a confidence level of 98%. Confirm identification by visually verifying the label text on the product.

Grasp Canned Tomatoes: Extend Robotic Arm Joint 1 an additional 0.1 meters. Initiate gripping action using the designated pneumatic gripper. Apply a gripping force of 5 Newtons. Maintain this grip for 1 second to ensure secure hold. Record grip force and duration in data log B.

Lift Canned Tomatoes: Raise Robotic Arm Joint 1 vertically by 0.4 meters. Maintain a stable horizontal position while lifting. Duration of lift: 0.8 seconds. Record lift trajectory and velocity data in data log C.

Place Canned Tomatoes on Designated Counter Surface: Lower Robotic Arm Joint 1 to a horizontal position 0.2 meters above the counter surface. Ensure the Canned Tomatoes are centered on the counter surface, within a tolerance of +/- 0.02 meters in both X and Y axes. Verify placement using the optical sensor.

Repeat Steps 3-6 for Ingredient 2 – Onions (1 medium): Navigate to Shelf 1, Level 1. Repeat grasping, lifting, and placement procedures, adjusting the target coordinates and grip force as necessary based on the onion's dimensions. Record all measurements and force values in data log C.

Repeat Steps 3-6 for Ingredient 3 – Garlic (3 cloves): Navigate to Shelf 2, Level 3. Repeat grasping, lifting, and placement procedures, adjusting the target coordinates and grip force as necessary based on the garlic's dimensions. Record all measurements and force values in data log C.
Final System Check: Activate Robotic Arm's self-diagnostic routine. Verify all joint movements, gripper functionality, and sensor readings. Record the completion status of the task in data log D.
Place Ingredients in Shopping Cart

Initialize Robotic Arm Position: Extend Robotic Arm Segment 1 to a horizontal position, maintaining a 37.5-degree angle relative to the floor. Confirm position using onboard visual sensor; target object ID: 'Cart_Base_01'.

Approach Cart Base: Move Robotic Arm Segment 1 at a speed of 0.15 meters per second. Maintain a vertical distance of 0.05 meters from the Cart Base. Adjust trajectory to ensure a direct approach path. Confirm approach using onboard lidar data.

Grasp Ingredient - Canned Tomatoes: Calculate precise Cartesian coordinates for the center of the Canned Tomatoes (based on visual recognition data - object ID: 'Tomatoes_01'). Move Robotic Arm Segment 2 to a 45-degree upward angle relative to the Cart Base. Execute a pinch grip action with a force of 2.5 Newtons for 0.5 seconds. Verify grip strength via force sensor.
Lift Ingredient - Canned Tomatoes: Raise Robotic Arm Segment 2 vertically by 0.3 meters. Maintain a stable hold. Monitor joint angles to ensure a consistent lift trajectory. Duration: 1.2 seconds.

Position Ingredient - Canned Tomatoes: Rotate Robotic Arm Segment 2 clockwise by 15 degrees. Lower the ingredient until the top of the Canned Tomatoes is 0.15 meters above the Cart Base surface. Confirm position using onboard visual sensor.

Release Ingredient - Canned Tomatoes: Decrease force applied by Robotic Arm Segment 2 to 0.0 Newtons over a 0.1-second decay. Allow the Canned Tomatoes to gently settle onto the Cart Base. Monitor impact force via accelerometer.
Retract Robotic Arm Segment 1: Move Robotic Arm Segment 1 back to its initial horizontal position (37.5-degree angle). Duration: 0.8 seconds.

Repeat Steps for Remaining Ingredients: Proceed to the next ingredient (e.g., Canned Beans) and repeat the entire process from Step 1 until all ingredients are placed in the cart. Maintain a separation distance of 0.05 meters between each placed item.
Proceed to Checkout

Initialize Robotic Arm Joint Positions: Simultaneously, activate Robotic Arm Joint 1 to 0.0 degrees, Joint 2 to -15.3 degrees, Joint 3 to 32.1 degrees, Joint 4 to 1.8 degrees, and Joint 5 to -8.4 degrees. Maintain this configuration for 0.5 seconds.

Navigate to Shopping Cart Position: Utilizing the onboard visual system, locate the shopping cart. Calculate the Euclidean distance to the cart: 1.8 meters. Initiate forward movement at a speed of 0.3 meters per second for 6.0 seconds. Verify position at 1.8 meters from initial location with onboard laser rangefinder.

Extend Robotic Arm Towards Shopping Cart Handle: Activate Robotic Arm Joint 1 to -5.2 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 2 to -22.7 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 3 to 28.9 degrees. Maintain this configuration for 1.2 seconds. Monitor cart handle proximity using onboard lidar, maintaining a distance of 0.1 meters.

Execute Cart Handle Grasp: Upon reaching 0.1 meters, activate Robotic Arm Joint 1 to 0.0 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 2 to -18.5 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 3 to 35.6 degrees. Apply a gripping force of 15 Newtons. Hold for 0.8 seconds.

Disengage Robotic Arm: Simultaneously, deactivate Robotic Arm Joint 1 to 0.0 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 2 to -1.3 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 3 to 29.4 degrees. Release gripping force to 0 Newtons. Hold for 0.3 seconds.

Navigate to Checkout Lane Position: Calculate the Euclidean distance to the checkout lane: 3.2 meters. Initiate forward movement at a speed of 0.4 meters per second for 8.0 seconds. Confirm position at 3.2 meters from previous location with onboard visual system.

Prepare for Payment Interaction: Position Robotic Arm Joint 1 to -3.1 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 2 to -10.7 degrees. Activate Robotic Arm Joint 3 to 31.5 degrees. Extend Robotic Arm to a position 0.2 meters from the payment terminal. Maintain this position for 1.0 seconds.
Await User Instruction: Halt all movement. Enter a ‘wait’ state for 5.0 seconds. Monitor environment for verbal instruction or visual cue indicating payment interaction.
Activate Yeast
Warm Water Preparation: Heat water to the specified temperature (typically 105-115°F / 40-46°C).

Initiate Water Heater Activation: Activate the designated water heater unit. Confirm activation via visual indicator light change from ‘off’ to ‘steady amber’ within 3 seconds. Record activation timestamp: [timestamp].

Verify Initial Water Temperature: Using a calibrated digital thermometer, insert the probe 5 centimeters into the water reservoir. Record initial water temperature. Ensure the thermometer displays a temperature between 10°C and 20°C.

Adjust Heating Element Power: Set the water heater’s control dial to the ‘Mid’ heating power setting. Monitor the control dial's rotational movement. Ensure the dial rotates 90 degrees from ‘Off’ to ‘Mid’ with a smooth, consistent movement. Record dial position: [dial_position].

Monitor Temperature Increase: Maintain the digital thermometer at the same location (5 cm depth). Record the water temperature every 10 seconds. Capture temperature readings at timestamps: [timestamp_1], [timestamp_2], [timestamp_3], [timestamp_4], [timestamp_5].

Implement Temperature Adjustment (if necessary): If the recorded temperature is below 40°C, increase the water heater’s control dial to the ‘High’ setting. If the temperature is above 46°C, decrease the dial to ‘Low’. Maintain precise control for temperature adjustments.

Achieve Target Temperature Range: Continue monitoring the water temperature every 5 seconds. Stop monitoring when the recorded temperature consistently reads between 40°C and 46°C, as measured by the digital thermometer. Record final temperature: [final_temperature] at timestamp: [timestamp_final].

Stabilize Water Temperature: Maintain the water heater at the ‘Mid’ setting for 30 seconds. Monitor the digital thermometer. Confirm temperature stability within ±0.5°C. Record final temperature stabilization timestamp: [timestamp_stabilization].

Confirm and Signal Completion: Activate the water heater’s visual indicator light to ‘steady green’ to indicate target temperature reached and stability. Log water temperature parameters: [final_temperature], [timestamp_final], [timestamp_stabilization].
Add Sugar: Dissolve a measured amount of sugar in the warm water.

Robot arm extends to grasp the measuring spoon (plastic, 15ml capacity) from its designated storage location (labeled ‘Sugar Utensils’, shelf level 3, position 2). Grip force: 2.5 Newtons. Movement duration: 0.7 seconds. Verify grip stability with force sensor reading (target: 2.7 Newtons +/- 0.2 Newtons).

Robot arm moves the measuring spoon to the designated sugar container (ceramic, 500g capacity). Precise horizontal positioning: X = 150mm, Y = 220mm, Z = 310mm. Movement duration: 1.2 seconds. Verify alignment with laser distance sensor (target distance: 230mm +/- 1mm).

Robot arm deposits the measuring spoon into the sugar container. Deposit height: 15mm above the sugar surface. Deposit force: 1.8 Newtons. Duration: 0.4 seconds. Monitor sugar level sensor for completion (target: 15ml +/- 0.5ml).
Robot arm retracts the measuring spoon, returning it to its original storage location. Movement duration: 1.1 seconds. Verify return path using visual marker recognition (target: visual marker ‘A’).

Robot arm extends to grasp the warm water container (stainless steel, 1.5L capacity). Grip force: 3.0 Newtons. Movement duration: 0.9 seconds. Verify grip stability with force sensor reading (target: 2.8 Newtons +/- 0.3 Newtons).

Robot arm moves the warm water container to the designated mixing vessel (plastic, 0.5L capacity). Precise horizontal positioning: X = 280mm, Y = 110mm, Z = 250mm. Movement duration: 1.5 seconds. Verify alignment with laser distance sensor (target distance: 245mm +/- 1mm).

Robot arm pours the warm water into the mixing vessel. Pour height: 400ml. Pour speed: 100ml/second. Monitor liquid level sensor for completion (target: 400ml +/- 10ml). Maintain a consistent pour angle of 30 degrees relative to the container surface.

Robot arm retracts the warm water container, returning it to its original storage location. Movement duration: 0.8 seconds. Verify return path using visual marker recognition (target: visual marker ‘B’).

Robot arm extends to grasp the measuring spoon (plastic, 15ml capacity) from its designated storage location (labeled ‘Sugar Utensils’, shelf level 3, position 2). Grip force: 2.5 Newtons. Movement duration: 0.7 seconds. Verify grip stability with force sensor reading (target: 2.7 Newtons +/- 0.2 Newtons).

Robot arm moves the measuring spoon to the mixing vessel. Precise horizontal positioning: X = 260mm, Y = 130mm, Z = 235mm. Movement duration: 1.0 seconds. Verify alignment with laser distance sensor (target distance: 240mm +/- 1mm).

Robot arm deposits the measuring spoon into the mixing vessel. Deposit height: 15mm above the liquid surface. Deposit force: 1.8 Newtons. Duration: 0.4 seconds. Monitor liquid level sensor for completion (target: 15ml +/- 0.5ml). Stir the mixture gently with the included mixing utensil (plastic, 10cm diameter) for 3 seconds prior to completion.
Activate Yeast: Sprinkle dry yeast over the sugar water.

Robot arm initiates movement towards designated mixing vessel (identified as Vessel-Alpha) using pre-programmed coordinates: X=0.25m, Y=0.78m, Z=-0.05m. Arm velocity: 0.1 m/s. Confirm position via visual sensor data analysis – target object confirmation required.

Robot arm adjusts manipulator end effector (designated End-Effector-7) to a neutral position with a 1.0 cm radius, ensuring a stable grip. Confirmation via tactile sensor feedback – pressure reading within 0.2-0.4 kPa.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a distance of 0.15 meters above the surface of the sugar water (identified as Liquid-Alpha) within Vessel-Alpha. Maintain a vertical axis alignment within +/- 0.01 degrees. Duration: 0.5 seconds.

Robot arm lowers End-Effector-7 directly above the center of the sugar water surface (identified as Center-Point-Alpha) within Vessel-Alpha. Precise horizontal adjustment within +/- 0.005m. Duration: 0.3 seconds.

Robot arm initiates a controlled downward movement of End-Effector-7, lowering the effector to a height of 0.03 meters above the sugar water surface. Velocity: 0.08 m/s.  Monitor liquid displacement using a downward-facing ultrasonic sensor. Stop movement when the sensor detects a consistent liquid level.
Robot arm maintains End-Effector-7 stationary at 0.03 meters above the sugar water surface for 0.8 seconds.  Stabilize arm position.  Monitor sensor data for vibrations exceeding 0.05g.

Robot arm initiates a dispensing action, releasing 3.0 grams of dry yeast (identified as Yeast-Sample-1) from the dispenser (designated Dispenser-Beta) directly onto the surface of the sugar water. Dispenser velocity: 0.05 m/s.  Monitor liquid displacement with ultrasonic sensor.
Robot arm maintains End-Effector-7 stationary over the sugar water surface for 2.0 seconds, ensuring complete yeast distribution. Monitor sensor data for residual yeast particles.
Robot arm retracts End-Effector-7 vertically by 0.03 meters. Velocity: 0.15 m/s. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Confirm retraction completion via sensor feedback.
Wait for Activation: Allow the yeast to sit for 5-10 minutes until it foams or bubbles.

Initialize Observation System: Activate visual sensor array designated 'YeastFoamDetector-Alpha'. Set field of view to 75 degrees horizontally, 45 degrees vertically, centered on the observation container designated 'YeastContainer-1'. Ensure sensor resolution is set to 1920x1080 pixels.
Establish Baseline Observation: Record initial image data from YeastFoamDetector-Alpha. Capture data for 3 seconds. Log data as 'BaselineImage-001'. Save to memory location 'ImageStorage-Yeast-01'.
Monitor for Foam Formation: Commence continuous monitoring of YeastFoamDetector-Alpha at a sampling rate of 10 frames per second. Maintain observation duration: 600 seconds (10 minutes).

Foam Detection Protocol: Implement image analysis algorithm 'FoamDetect-v3'. Algorithm parameters: Threshold 150, Variance 5. Analyze each frame for the presence of bubbles or foam. The presence of foam is defined as a pixel value exceeding the threshold in at least 20% of the image area. Log ‘FoamDetected’ status for each frame.

Movement Correction: If the observation container (YeastContainer-1) is not perfectly level, adjust the container's tilt using the servo motor designated 'LevelingServo-1'. Target tilt angle: 0.01 degrees ± 0.001 degrees. Monitor tilt angle using the angular encoder ‘TiltEncoder-1’. Maintain this correction continuously during the observation period.

Data Logging: For each frame processed by FoamDetect-v3, record the frame number, pixel data intensity distribution, and FoamDetected status in the log file ‘YeastFoamObservationLog-1’. Timestamp each entry with nanosecond accuracy.

Confirmation of Activation: The observation period ends when the FoamDetected status transitions to ‘True’ for a minimum of 3 consecutive frames. Confirm activation by logging the final frame number and the FoamDetected status.
Sensor Shutdown: Deactivate YeastFoamDetector-Alpha. Reduce sensor power consumption to 10% of nominal level. Log sensor shutdown event.
Verify Yeast Activity: Check for sufficient foam – a good indication of active yeast.
Robot arm initiates movement. Joint 1 (shoulder) rotates 15 degrees clockwise. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Maintain a stable, consistent rotational speed of 0.05 radians per second.

Robot arm extends arm segment 1, measuring 750 millimeters from the base of the container to the tip of the arm. Ensure arm segment 1 is perpendicular to the container surface with an accuracy of +/- 0.1 degrees.

Robot arm manipulates the arm segment 1 tip to precisely position it 20 millimeters above the center of the yeast mixture, measured from the horizontal plane passing through the container’s center.  Maintain a stable position at this height for 0.2 seconds.

Robot arm activates the integrated optical sensor. The sensor's focal length is adjusted to 50 millimeters. The sensor's field of view is centered on the yeast mixture. Sensor gain is set to 100. Record initial image data.
Robot arm maintains a constant vertical position of 20 millimeters above the yeast mixture.  No adjustments are made to the arm's vertical position. Duration: 3 seconds.

Robot arm activates the integrated image processing module. The module analyzes the sensor's output image. The analysis focuses on identifying areas of foam within the sensor’s field of view.  Threshold for foam detection is defined as a pixel brightness value greater than 150.

Robot arm calculates the area of foam detected within the sensor’s field of view. The calculation is based on pixels meeting the foam detection threshold. The result is expressed in square millimeters.

Robot arm compares the calculated foam area to a pre-defined reference value of 30 square millimeters.  This value represents the minimum acceptable foam level for this yeast strain under these conditions. The comparison is performed using a floating-point comparison with an epsilon of 0.1.

Robot arm outputs a binary result: 'Foam Sufficient' if the calculated foam area is greater than or equal to 30 square millimeters. ‘Foam Insufficient’ otherwise. Store the result as a digital flag (FLAG_FOAM_STATUS).

Robot arm retracts arm segment 1, returning to its initial position. Joint 1 (shoulder) rotates 15 degrees counter-clockwise. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Maintain a stable, consistent rotational speed of 0.05 radians per second.
Combine Wet Ingredients
Measure Wet Ingredients: Accurately measure the required amounts of liquids like milk, water, or juice.

Robot arm initializes to standby position: Arm joint 1 (shoulder) angle = 0 degrees, joint 2 (elbow) angle = 90 degrees, joint 3 (wrist) rotation = 0 degrees. Verify arm position using integrated laser scanner – target: Center of designated measurement area (coordinates: X=10.2 cm, Y=15.8 cm, Z=20.5 cm). Ensure gripper is closed, but not applying pressure.

Locate Liquid Container 1 (Milk): Using visual recognition system, identify container with label ‘Whole Milk’. Confirm container volume is 250 ml. Acquire precise 3D scan of container dimensions: Diameter = 8.1 cm, Height = 12.3 cm, Top Radius = 7.9 cm. Record scan data.

Position Robot Arm: Calculate approach vector to container's base. Vector components: X = -2.5 cm, Y = 3.1 cm, Z = 1.8 cm. Execute robot arm movement to reach the container's base with a final approach angle of 10 degrees relative to the container’s longitudinal axis. Confirm position using laser scanner - target: Center of container base (coordinates: X=8.6 cm, Y=18.9 cm, Z=20.5 cm). Speed: 50 mm/s.

Activate Gripper: Initiate gripper force regulation to 0.5 Newtons. Extend gripper arm 3.8 cm. Verify gripper tip placement on container base – tolerance +/- 0.2 cm. Monitor gripper pressure sensor readings. Maintain pressure until visual confirmation of secure grip.

Raise Container: Slowly raise container vertically by 5.0 cm. Monitor container tilt angle – maintain angle between 0 and 5 degrees. Use integrated inclinometer for precise angle control. Verify container remains stable. Duration: 2 seconds.

Measure Liquid Volume: Activate volumetric measurement system. Target volume: 125 ml.  Robot arm extends vertically by 7.5 cm, raising the container until the liquid level reaches the integrated ultrasonic sensor. Record ultrasonic sensor reading (target: 125 ml). Duration: 3 seconds.

Lower Container: Slowly retract robot arm vertically by 5.0 cm, lowering the container. Monitor container tilt angle – maintain angle between 0 and 5 degrees. Use integrated inclinometer for precise angle control. Confirm liquid level at the base of the container. Duration: 3 seconds.
Release Container: Deactivate gripper force regulation to 0.0 Newtons. Retract gripper arm to initial position (3.8 cm). Verify gripper is fully open. Record gripper opening time: < 1 second.

Container Position Adjustment: Using robot arm, adjust container position to the designated waste disposal area (coordinates: X=25.1 cm, Y=17.3 cm, Z=20.5 cm). Speed: 60 mm/s. Verify container placement within tolerance (+/- 1.0 cm).
Pour Wet Ingredients into a Bowl: Transfer the measured wet ingredients into a mixing bowl.

Initialize Robotic Arm: Activate Robotic Arm designated 'Arm-Alpha'. Verify joint angles are within acceptable range: Shoulder Rotation - 0.0 degrees, Elbow Rotation - 0.0 degrees, Wrist Rotation - 0.0 degrees. Confirm gripper pressure is set to 5 Newtons.

Locate Liquid Container: Using visual sensor 'Sight-01', identify the container holding 250 milliliters of water. Precise location coordinates: X = 1.2 meters, Y = 0.8 meters, Z = 0.3 meters. Confirm container orientation: upright, label facing forward.

Approach Liquid Container: Move Arm-Alpha towards the identified liquid container. Execute a linear trajectory with a velocity of 0.3 meters per second. Maintain a horizontal distance of 0.05 meters from the container’s edge.

Grasp Liquid Container: At a distance of 0.1 meters from the container’s rim, activate gripper on Arm-Alpha. Ensure gripper closes until a force sensor registers 15 Newtons of pressure. Maintain this pressure for 0.5 seconds.

Lift Liquid Container: Slowly raise the liquid container a vertical distance of 0.2 meters. Maintain a constant lifting speed of 0.1 meters per second. Monitor container stability using gyroscope readings – maintain roll angle < 0.1 degrees.

Transport Liquid Container: Move Arm-Alpha, with the grasped liquid container, horizontally to the designated mixing bowl. Precise bowl coordinates: X = 2.5 meters, Y = 1.9 meters, Z = 0.25 meters. Maintain a velocity of 0.4 meters per second. Avoid collisions with surrounding objects within a 0.1-meter radius.

Position Above Mixing Bowl: At a distance of 0.15 meters above the center of the mixing bowl, pause Arm-Alpha’s movement. Confirm bowl center is within the gripper’s operational range (0.2-0.3 meters horizontally). Adjust gripper position as needed to center the container above the bowl.

Release Liquid Container: Deactivate gripper on Arm-Alpha. Release the container. Monitor container descent. Implement a soft stop sequence – gradually reduce gripper pressure to 0 Newtons over 0.3 seconds. Confirm container lands gently within the mixing bowl, no more than 2 centimeters from the bowl’s center.

Verify Liquid Level: Activate visual sensor 'Sight-02' to confirm 250 milliliters of liquid is present in the mixing bowl. Record visual confirmation for 3 seconds. Trigger alert if liquid level deviates by more than 5 milliliters.
Assess Ingredient Consistency: Observe the initial texture and consistency of the wet ingredients before combining.

Robot arm initializes to neutral position, with end effector (stainless steel spatula attachment) at 100mm above the surface of the 'Ingredient Vessel A' (designated Vessel A). Arm speed: 50mm/s. Maintain a 3-degree tilt towards the center of Vessel A.

Robot arm extends vertically until the spatula attachment reaches a height of 30mm above the surface of Vessel A. Arm speed: 30mm/s. Confirm position via visual sensor (RGB camera) – image recognition must identify a consistent surface across at least 50% of Vessel A's visible surface.

Robot arm applies a downward force of 1.5 Newtons to the surface of Vessel A, maintaining contact for 0.75 seconds. Monitor surface displacement via capacitive sensor. Displacement must not exceed 0.2mm.

Robot arm retracts vertically by 15mm. Arm speed: 40mm/s. Observe the resulting surface impression for 0.5 seconds. Record the area of the impression using the integrated laser rangefinder – measurement must be within +/- 0.1mm.

Robot arm repositions to a new location: 20mm to the right and 10mm forward of the initial position. Arm speed: 60mm/s. Confirm position via visual sensor – image recognition must identify a consistent surface across at least 50% of Vessel A's visible surface.
Repeat step 3, applying a downward force of 1.5 Newtons for 0.75 seconds and recording the surface displacement and area using the capacitive sensor and laser rangefinder, respectively.
Robot arm repeats step 2 and 3 a second time, changing the location by 15mm to the left and 5mm forward.
Robot arm returns to the initial neutral position, with the end effector at 100mm above the surface of Vessel A. Arm speed: 50mm/s.

Data acquisition: Transmit recorded measurements (force, displacement, area) and corresponding visual sensor data (RGB image) to the central processing unit for analysis. Timestamp data to the nearest 0.1 second.
Mix Dry Ingredients
Measure Dry Ingredients: Accurately scoop and measure the required amounts of flour, baking powder, salt, and any other dry ingredients specified in the recipe.
Ensure Accurate Measurement: Use proper measuring tools (cups, spoons) for precise quantities.

Robot arm extends to grasp designated measuring cup (250 ml capacity) from storage shelf. Arm extension velocity: 0.1 meters per second. Confirm grip stability with force sensor – target force: 2.5 Newtons. Maintain grip for 0.5 seconds.

Robot arm rotates cup 90 degrees clockwise. Rotation speed: 3 radians per second. Verify cup orientation using visual marker recognition – target marker position: 1.2 meters ahead, 0.8 meters to the right.

Robot arm extends into designated dry ingredients container (flour). Utilize suction nozzle to gently lift 50 grams of flour. Monitor weight sensor – target weight: 50.00 grams +/- 0.01 grams. Maintain suction for 1.0 seconds.

Robot arm precisely deposits the lifted flour into the 250 ml measuring cup. Deposition height above cup rim: 1.5 centimeters. Deposition velocity: 0.08 meters per second. Duration of deposition: 2.0 seconds. Confirm full cup fill with visual confirmation – target flour level: 95% of cup volume.

Robot arm retracts to initial position. Arm retraction velocity: 0.15 meters per second. Pause at initial position for 0.2 seconds. Record current arm position data (x, y, z coordinates) for later comparison.
Repeat steps 1-5 with designated measuring spoon (15 ml capacity) and 10 grams of sugar. Spoon rotation angle: 180 degrees clockwise. Confirm sugar weight at 10.00 grams +/- 0.01 grams.
Robot arm returns to storage location for measuring cup and spoon. Record final position data.
Robot arm initiates cleaning cycle for measuring tools – ultrasonic cleaning for 30 seconds at 40 kHz.
Combine Dry Ingredients in Bowl: Transfer all measured dry ingredients into a clean mixing bowl.
Clean Bowl: Ensure the bowl is free from any debris or contaminants.

Robot arm to approach Bowl. Initiate approach sequence. Target coordinates: X = 0.1 meters, Y = 0.2 meters, Z = 0.05 meters. Approach velocity: 0.05 meters per second. Maintain a 3-degree visual angle to the Bowl's center. Duration: 2.5 seconds.

Activate optical sensor. Initiate image analysis. Scan Bowl surface for visible debris. Resolution: 1920x1080 pixels. Frame rate: 30 FPS. Collect image data for subsequent debris identification. Duration: 1.0 second.

Identify Debris Objects. Utilize image processing algorithm to detect and classify objects smaller than 2mm within the Bowl’s image. Output: List of identified debris objects with coordinates (X, Y, Z) relative to the Bowl's center, and classification (e.g., 'Food Particle', 'Liquid Residue'). Duration: 3.0 seconds.

Select Cleaning Tool. Based on identified debris classification, select appropriate cleaning tool from tool catalog. Tool identified: Soft Bristle Brush. Tool type: Rotating Brush. Brush diameter: 1.5 cm. Brush speed: 150 RPM. Duration: 0.5 seconds.

Position Cleaning Tool. Robot arm to adjust its position to be directly above the identified debris. Target coordinates: X = 0.15 meters, Y = 0.2 meters, Z = 0.1 meters. Adjust Z-axis vertically by 0.02 meters. Duration: 1.5 seconds.

Execute Brush Movement. Activate rotating brush. Initiate brush rotation. Brush contact point with Bowl surface: Center of Bowl’s base. Brush pressure: 0.5 Newtons. Brush rotation duration: 5.0 seconds. Monitor brush rotation speed via sensor feedback. Duration: 5.0 seconds.

Verify Debris Removal. Activate optical sensor. Initiate image analysis. Scan Bowl surface for debris. Resolution: 1920x1080 pixels. Frame rate: 30 FPS. Compare processed image to pre-cleaning image. Threshold for debris detection reduction: 80%. Duration: 2.0 seconds.
Repeat Brush Movement (if necessary). If debris detection threshold is not met, repeat Step 5 and Step 6. Maximum repetitions: 3. Duration: 6.0 seconds (including both brush movements).

Clean Bowl Surface with Sanitizing Solution. Dispense 2.0 ml of sanitizing solution (concentration: 1% sodium hypochlorite) onto the Bowl's surface. Dispensing nozzle position: X = 0.18 meters, Y = 0.21 meters, Z = 0.08 meters. Dispense duration: 3.0 seconds. Duration: 3.0 seconds.
Wipe Bowl Surface. Activate microfiber cloth. Initiate wiping motion. Wiping surface area: 8cm x 8cm. Wiping speed: 0.2 meters per second. Wiping duration: 5.0 seconds. Duration: 5.0 seconds.
Whisk Dry Ingredients: Thoroughly whisk the dry ingredients together to ensure even distribution.
Eliminate Clumps: Pay attention to removing any clumps of flour or other dry ingredients.

Initialize Robotic Arm: Activate robotic arm designated 'FlourEliminator-734'. Verify arm joint angles are at 0.0 degrees for all axes (X, Y, Z). Confirm gripper pressure sensors are at 1.2 Newtons. Initiate visual tracking system, focusing on designated work area – 0.5m x 0.7m.

Scan for Clumps: Activate visual scanning system. Analyze image data for areas exceeding 3mm in diameter exhibiting irregular texture or color variation consistent with dry ingredient clumps. Record coordinates of identified clumps – precision ± 1mm. Store coordinates in memory bank ‘ClumpData-1’. Perform scan duration: 3 seconds.

Approach Clump 1: Calculate optimal approach trajectory to target clump identified in ‘ClumpData-1’. Trajectory should be a straight line, perpendicular to the clump's estimated center. Calculate approach distance: 150mm.  Initiate linear motion along the calculated trajectory at a speed of 50mm/second. Monitor visual feedback for potential obstructions.

Grasp Clump 1: Upon reaching 75mm from the clump's center, activate gripper pressure sensors to 3.5 Newtons. Execute a downward motion of 10mm. Verify gripper contacts the surface of the flour clump. Confirm grip stability using tactile sensor input – target reading: 2.8 Newtons. Hold for 0.5 seconds.

Separate Clump 1: Initiate rotational motion of gripper axis Y at a speed of 10 degrees/second for 2 seconds.  Maintain gripper pressure at 3.5 Newtons. Observe visual feedback – target is to separate the clump from the surrounding surface. Ensure no secondary flour displacement greater than 2mm in any direction.

Release Clump 1: Halt rotational motion. Reduce gripper pressure to 1.2 Newtons. Initiate a vertical lift of 5mm.  Observe the separated flour sample.  Maintain position for 0.2 seconds.  Record location of released flour sample – precision ± 0.5mm.  Store coordinates in memory bank ‘FlourSample-1’.

Repeat Steps 2-5 for Clump 2: Analyze image data for a second clump meeting the criteria defined in Step 2. Calculate trajectory and execute approach, grasp, separation, and release as described in previous steps. Target Clump 2 coordinates: 0.3m x 0.4m.  Maintain process time between clump analysis and action: 15 seconds.

Repeat Steps 2-5 for Clump 3: Analyze image data for a third clump meeting the criteria defined in Step 2. Calculate trajectory and execute approach, grasp, separation, and release as described in previous steps. Target Clump 3 coordinates: 0.6m x 0.8m. Maintain process time between clump analysis and action: 15 seconds.
Assess Initial Mixing: Observe the mixture for uniformity of color and texture.

Robot arm initializes to position X: 0.5 meters, Y: -0.2 meters, Z: 1.8 meters.  Robot arm gripper is in the closed position with a closing force of 1.2 Newtons. Maintain this position for 0.5 seconds.
Robot arm extends vertically, raising the gripper to Z: 2.0 meters.  Extension speed: 15 centimeters per second.  Duration: 0.8 seconds.  Maintain this height.
Robot arm rotates horizontally 90 degrees clockwise. Rotation speed: 30 degrees per second. Duration: 1.2 seconds.  End rotation at orientation: X: 0.5 meters, Y: -0.2 meters, Z: 2.0 meters.

Robot arm lowers the gripper to a contact point with the mixture surface. Precise contact point is defined as the centroid of the mixture within a 5cm radius. Monitor contact force - maintain force of 0.8 Newtons. Duration: 0.3 seconds.

Robot arm applies a vertical force of 0.5 Newtons to the mixture. Duration: 1.0 second.  Monitor the mixture's visual response – record color change (RGB values: Red: 120, Green: 130, Blue: 140). Record video feed for 0.5 seconds.
Robot arm retracts the gripper vertically 10 centimeters. Retraction speed: 20 centimeters per second. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Return to original Z: 2.0 meters.
Robot arm rotates horizontally 90 degrees counter-clockwise. Rotation speed: 30 degrees per second. Duration: 0.8 seconds. End rotation at orientation: X: 0.5 meters, Y: -0.2 meters, Z: 2.0 meters.
Robot arm extends vertically, raising the gripper to Z: 2.1 meters. Extension speed: 15 centimeters per second. Duration: 0.7 seconds. Maintain this height.

Robot arm applies a vertical force of 0.6 Newtons to the mixture. Duration: 1.5 seconds. Monitor the mixture's visual response – record color change (RGB values: Red: 118, Green: 128, Blue: 132). Record video feed for 0.7 seconds.
Robot arm retracts the gripper vertically 10 centimeters. Retraction speed: 20 centimeters per second. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Return to original Z: 2.0 meters.
Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients
Measure Wet Ingredients: Accurately measure the required amounts of liquids like milk, water, or juice.

Initiate Measurement Protocol: Activate visual sensor array designated ‘Liquid Measurement Unit 734’. Confirm sensor calibration status – target value: 0.000 ± 0.001 ml. Audible confirmation: ‘Calibration Complete’.”

Locate Container 1: Identify and confirm the physical location of container designated ‘Milk Jug – 1L’ based on visual marker ‘Blue Circle – 15cm’. Verify container material: Polypropylene. Container orientation: Vertical

Position Measurement Device: Move robotic arm segment 3 (designated ‘Arm Segment 3’) to a position 25cm directly above the opening of ‘Milk Jug – 1L’. Arm Segment 3 should be oriented with its central axis pointing directly upwards.”

Lower Measurement Device: Lower the ‘Digital Volume Measurement Device – VMD-2000’ (a cylindrical probe with integrated digital scale) vertically until the probe tip is 2cm from the container opening. Ensure the probe tip remains stationary.”

Initiate Liquid Transfer: Activate the ‘Internal Pump – LP-1’ at a flow rate of 1.0 ml/second. Maintain flow until the digital scale reads 250.0 ml. Monitor scale reading with continuous visual updates.”
Pause Liquid Transfer: Upon reaching 250.0 ml
Raise Measurement Device: Raise the ‘Digital Volume Measurement Device – VMD-2000’ vertically by 5cm. Maintain probe tip stationary.”
Repeat Measurement: Initiate ‘Internal Pump – LP-1’ at 1.0 ml/second until the digital scale reads 250.0 ml. Audible confirmation: ‘Transfer Complete – 250.0 ml’.”

Final Volume Confirmation: Verify the final liquid volume in ‘Milk Jug – 1L’ is 250.0 ml using visual confirmation from the ‘Digital Volume Measurement Device – VMD-2000’. If within tolerance (+/- 0.1 ml)
Document Measurement: Record the final volume reading (250.0 ml) and timestamp into the ‘Liquid Measurement Log – ML-12’. Update operational status to ‘Measurement Complete’.”

Retract Robotic Arm: Raise ‘Arm Segment 3’ vertically by 10cm and return to default resting position. Initiate cleaning cycle for ‘Digital Volume Measurement Device – VMD-2000’ with detergent solution.”
Pour Wet Ingredients into a Bowl: Transfer the measured wet ingredients into a mixing bowl.
Robot arm initializes to neutral position, with gripper positioned 15.0 centimeters above the mixing bowl's center. Gripper rotation angle: 0 degrees.
Robot arm extends vertically, moving the gripper to a position 22.5 centimeters above the center of the mixing bowl. Movement speed: 50 millimeters per second. Duration: 0.7 seconds.
Robot arm adjusts gripper rotation angle to 45 degrees. Rotation speed: 30 degrees per second. Duration: 0.3 seconds.

Robot arm lowers the gripper until the cup containing 120 milliliters of milk is positioned directly above the mixing bowl's center. Precise vertical displacement: 10.0 millimeters. Duration: 0.2 seconds.
Robot gripper closes with a force of 2.0 Newtons. Hold duration: 0.5 seconds. Gripper pressure sensor reading must remain stable (within 0.1 Newtons).
Robot arm lifts the cup containing the milk 15.0 centimeters vertically. Movement speed: 40 millimeters per second. Duration: 1.2 seconds.
Robot arm moves the cup directly above the mixing bowl’s center. Horizontal displacement: 7.5 centimeters. Movement speed: 60 millimeters per second. Duration: 0.6 seconds.
Robot arm begins pouring liquid. Dispensing rate: 15 milliliters per second. Dispense for a duration of 8 seconds. Monitor liquid level within the cup via optical sensor.
Upon completion of the 8-second dispense, robot arm immediately retracts the cup 20.0 centimeters vertically. Movement speed: 55 millimeters per second. Duration: 0.8 seconds.
Robot arm returns to initial neutral position. Gripper rotation angle: 0 degrees. Arm extension: 15.0 centimeters. Movement speed: 45 millimeters per second. Duration: 1.2 seconds.
Measure Dry Ingredients: Accurately scoop and measure the required amounts of flour, baking powder, salt, and any other dry ingredients specified in the recipe.

Initialize Measuring Tools: Position the digital kitchen scale on a stable, level surface. Ensure the surface has a non-reactive, smooth finish (stainless steel or glass recommended). Calibrate the scale to zero with no objects present. Verify calibration by pressing and holding the ‘Tare’ button for 3 seconds until the display reads ‘0.000’ with no decimal places. Maintain this calibration for the duration of the measurement process.

Retrieve Flour Container: Extend robotic arm segment 1 to a reach of 1.2 meters. Rotate arm segment 1 to an orientation of 15 degrees relative to vertical. Utilize end effector ‘A’ (scoop attachment) to grasp the flour container. Apply a grasping force of 1.5 Newtons, maintaining contact with the container’s base for 0.5 seconds. Lift the container to a height of 0.7 meters above the scale surface.

Scoop Flour: Activate scoop attachment ‘A’’s mechanism to initiate a scooping motion. Lower scoop attachment ‘A’ until the bottom of the scoop makes contact with the flour surface. Apply a downward force of 2.0 Newtons for 0.3 seconds to extract approximately 30 grams of flour. Maintain scoop attachment ‘A’’s position at a consistent distance (1.5 cm) above the flour surface throughout the scooping action. Do not introduce any extraneous movement.

Deposit Flour: Raise scoop attachment ‘A’ to a height of 0.3 meters above the scale platform. Slowly lower scoop attachment ‘A’ until it makes contact with the scale platform. Apply a controlled downward force of 1.0 Newton for 0.2 seconds to allow the flour to settle onto the scale. Immediately retract scoop attachment ‘A’ to a position 2 cm above the scale platform.

Record Flour Weight: Wait for the scale to stabilize. Record the displayed weight in the database. Ensure that the displayed weight is within a tolerance of +/- 0.1 grams. If the weight falls outside this tolerance, repeat steps 3 and 4.

Clean Scoop Attachment: Rotate arm segment 1 to an orientation of -45 degrees relative to vertical. Deploy a cleaning wipe (lint-free microfiber) from storage unit 3. Initiate a circular scrubbing motion with the wipe covering the entire surface area of scoop attachment ‘A’ for 2 seconds, applying a constant pressure of 0.5 Newtons. Store the cleaning wipe back into storage unit 3.

Repeat for Baking Powder: Repeat steps 1 through 6, using scoop attachment ‘A’ and the designated scoop depth for baking powder. Ensure the baking powder container is grasped and manipulated with the same precision and force as the flour container.
Repeat for Salt: Repeat steps 1 through 6, using scoop attachment ‘A’ and the designated scoop depth for salt.
Repeat for Other Dry Ingredients: Repeat steps 1 through 6, using scoop attachment ‘A’ and the designated scoop depth for each other specified dry ingredient.
Combine Dry Ingredients in Bowl: Transfer all measured dry ingredients into the mixing bowl with the wet ingredients.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a position 35 centimeters above the designated mixing bowl. Verify manipulator arm angle is 15 degrees relative to vertical. Confirm grip sensor is active and reporting pressure of 1.2 Newtons.
Robot arm retracts manipulator arm 10 centimeters. Verify manipulator arm angle remains at 15 degrees. Confirm grip sensor pressure is stable at 1.2 Newtons.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a position 20 centimeters above the designated mixing bowl. Verify manipulator arm angle is 17 degrees relative to vertical. Confirm grip sensor is active and reporting pressure of 1.5 Newtons.
Robot arm retracts manipulator arm 15 centimeters. Verify manipulator arm angle remains at 17 degrees. Confirm grip sensor pressure is stable at 1.5 Newtons.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a position 30 centimeters above the mixing bowl. Verify manipulator arm angle is 19 degrees relative to vertical. Confirm grip sensor is active and reporting pressure of 1.8 Newtons.
Robot arm retracts manipulator arm 12 centimeters. Verify manipulator arm angle remains at 19 degrees. Confirm grip sensor pressure is stable at 1.8 Newtons.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a position 25 centimeters above the mixing bowl. Verify manipulator arm angle is 21 degrees relative to vertical. Confirm grip sensor is active and reporting pressure of 2.0 Newtons.

Robot arm retracts manipulator arm 8 centimeters. Verify manipulator arm angle remains at 21 degrees. Confirm grip sensor pressure is stable at 2.0 Newtons. Initiate bowl rotation at 60 degrees per second for 3 seconds.

Robot arm extends manipulator arm to a position 15 centimeters above the mixing bowl. Verify manipulator arm angle is 23 degrees relative to vertical. Confirm grip sensor is active and reporting pressure of 2.2 Newtons.

Robot arm retracts manipulator arm 5 centimeters. Verify manipulator arm angle remains at 23 degrees. Confirm grip sensor pressure is stable at 2.2 Newtons. Halt bowl rotation. Confirm ingredients are evenly distributed within the bowl.
Mix Until Just Combined: Gently mix the wet and dry ingredients together until they are just combined. Avoid overmixing.

Robot arm initiates movement towards the mixing bowl. Arm extension: 0.7 meters. Target acquisition time: 0.3 seconds. Verify bowl center coordinates: X=0.1 meters, Y=0.2 meters, Z=0.05 meters. Adjust arm trajectory to intercept target.

Robot arm effector (mixer attachment) approaches the bowl's surface. Distance from surface: 2.0 centimeters. Speed: 50 millimeters per second. Maintain a perpendicular angle to the bowl's surface (90 degrees +/- 0.5 degrees).

Robot arm effector applies a downward force of 1.5 Newtons to the dry ingredient pile. Duration: 0.8 seconds. Monitor force sensor reading; maintain constant force. Target depth of dry ingredient incorporation: 3.0 centimeters.

Robot arm effector executes a clockwise rotation of 90 degrees. Rotation speed: 30 degrees per second. Duration: 3 seconds. Observe visual confirmation of ingredient incorporation through camera feed. Monitor for visible streaks of dry ingredient.

Robot arm effector introduces the wet ingredient. Volume: 120 milliliters. Dispense rate: 10 milliliters per second. Maintain a distance of 5.0 centimeters from the dry ingredients. Duration: 12 seconds. Precise delivery; confirm complete integration.

Robot arm effector executes a slow, 360-degree counter-clockwise rotation. Rotation speed: 10 degrees per second. Duration: 36 seconds. Monitor visual confirmation through camera feed; stop rotation when all dry ingredients are evenly dispersed and no visible streaks remain.

Robot arm effector maintains a stationary position above the mixing bowl. Arm extension: 0.7 meters. Duration: 5 seconds. Monitor visual confirmation via camera feed. Analyze mixture for visual signs of overmixing (e.g., excessive foam, sheen). Record mixture viscosity via embedded sensor.
If visual analysis indicates overmixing (viscosity reading exceeds 1.2 Pa·s): Reduce robot arm speed to 10 millimeters per second for 3 seconds.  Otherwise, terminate step.
Robot arm effector ceases all movement. Arm extension: 0.7 meters. Duration: 2 seconds.  Record final mixture viscosity.  Confirm viscosity within specified range (1.0 - 1.3 Pa·s).
Knead Dough
Prepare the Dough Surface: Lightly flour a clean work surface.

Initiate Robotic Arm Movement: Extend Robotic Arm Segment 1 to position designated as 'Flour Acquisition Point'. Arm Segment 1 should be oriented at an angle of 37.5 degrees relative to the vertical, with a horizontal displacement of 0.2 meters from the center of the work surface. Maintain arm stability at 0.01 Newton.

Activate Flour Dispenser: Engage Flour Dispenser Motor for a duration of 0.5 seconds. Target flour release volume: 15 grams. Monitor dispenser output via optical sensor; cease operation when 15 grams have been dispensed.

Precise Flour Delivery: Execute Robotic Arm Movement: Extend Robotic Arm Segment 2 from the Flour Acquisition Point to a point 0.3 meters directly ahead of Robotic Arm Segment 1. Arm Segment 2 should maintain a constant vertical displacement of 0.15 meters. Movement speed: 0.1 meters per second.

Flour Distribution Pattern: Initiate Rotating Flouring Mechanism. Rotate the flourier mechanism at a speed of 1 revolution per 5 seconds. Maintain a consistent flour dispersal radius of 0.1 meters from the robotic arm's center. Monitor flour distribution via a laser grid to ensure uniform coverage.

Work Surface Area Scanning: Activate Work Surface Scanning Array. Scan the designated work surface area (dimensions: 0.8 meters x 0.6 meters) at a resolution of 100 pixels per meter. Record data relating to flour density using infrared sensors.

Flour Density Correction: Based on Work Surface Scanning Array data, adjust Flour Distribution Pattern speed by +/- 10%. Implement adjustments via PID control loop with a target flour density of 0.02 grams per square centimeter.
Secondary Flour Application: Repeat Flour Distribution Pattern steps 3-6 for an additional 3 seconds. Maintain constant monitoring of the work surface density via laser grid.

Final Density Verification: Conduct final Work Surface Scanning Array scan. Compare measured flour density to target 0.02 grams per square centimeter. Implement final adjustment to Flour Distribution Pattern speed as required to achieve target density.

Surface Stabilization: Initiate Robotic Arm Movement: Extend Robotic Arm Segment 1 to a position 0.1 meters to the right of the work surface. Arm Segment 1 should maintain a constant vertical displacement of 0.1 meters. Hold this position for 2 seconds to allow the flour to settle.
Add Flour: Pour the measured flour onto the floured work surface.
Robot arm actuator 1 to extend to pre-programmed position: X = 0.3 meters, Y = 0.15 meters, Z = 0.4 meters. Maintain position for 0.5 seconds to ensure stable engagement.
Robot arm actuator 2 to extend to pre-programmed position: X = 0.45 meters, Y = 0.18 meters, Z = 0.4 meters. Maintain position for 0.5 seconds to ensure stable engagement.
Robot arm to execute linear motion: Move along the X-axis from 0.3 meters to 0.45 meters over a duration of 1.0 seconds. Velocity: 0.1 meters per second.
Upon reaching the destination coordinates (0.45 meters, 0.18 meters, 0.4 meters), activate the dispensing mechanism. Dispensing duration: 0.3 seconds.
Dispensing mechanism to release 200 grams of flour. Precise measurement to be verified by integrated weight sensor. Deviation tolerance: +/- 2 grams.
Immediately following flour release, activate the stirring mechanism. Stirring speed: 100 RPM. Duration: 2.0 seconds.

Monitor flour distribution visually via integrated camera. Capture image at 30 frames per second for 5 seconds. Analyze image for uniform distribution. Flag any significant clumps exceeding 5mm in diameter.
If uneven distribution detected (based on image analysis), deactivate the stirring mechanism. Activate the rotating turntable at 10 RPM for 3.0 seconds to redistribute the flour.
After turntable rotation, repeat image analysis (Step 7) to verify flour distribution.
If distribution remains uneven, repeat steps 7 and 8 until flour is uniformly distributed or a maximum of 5 iterations are completed.
Incorporate Wet Ingredients: Add all of the wet ingredients to the flour.

Robot arm initiates movement towards mixing bowl. Precise target coordinates: X = 0.2 meters, Y = 0.8 meters, Z = 0.3 meters. Arm velocity: 0.1 meters/second. Maintain a 3-degree downward angle relative to the bowl surface.

Robot arm extends spatula attachment (stainless steel, 10cm blade) to a length of 0.15 meters.  Spatula orientation: 0 degrees relative to the bowl’s horizontal plane.  Spatula velocity: 0.15 meters/second.  Adjust arm position to intercept the first wet ingredient container (100ml milk) at coordinates X = 0.3 meters, Y = 0.7 meters, Z = 0.2 meters.

Spatula descends vertically at a rate of 0.2 meters/second until the blade is 0.02 meters above the milk surface.  Maintain a static position for 0.5 seconds to allow complete transfer.  Monitor sensor data to verify blade position within +/- 0.005 meters of target.

Initiate stirring action. Spatula rotates clockwise at 60 RPM for 3 seconds. Monitor liquid displacement volume using integrated sensor.  Ensure consistent mixing while maintaining static blade position.

Robot arm retracts spatula attachment 0.08 meters to maintain a safe distance from the bowl contents. Arm velocity: 0.1 meters/second. Target coordinates: X = 0.2 meters, Y = 0.8 meters, Z = 0.5 meters.
Repeat steps 3 and 4 with the second wet ingredient (50ml water) at coordinates X = 0.4 meters, Y = 0.7 meters, Z = 0.2 meters.  Ensure complete mixing after each addition.
Repeat steps 3 and 4 with the third wet ingredient (25ml melted butter) at coordinates X = 0.35 meters, Y = 0.65 meters, Z = 0.25 meters.  Monitor for any separation or clumping.
Final mixing action: Rotate spatula clockwise at 40 RPM for 5 seconds. Monitor for complete integration of all wet ingredients. Sensor data must confirm homogenous mixture.
Robot arm raises spatula attachment to a height of 0.1 meters above the bowl surface. Arm velocity: 0.1 meters/second. Target coordinates: X = 0.2 meters, Y = 0.8 meters, Z = 0.6 meters.
Begin Kneading: Use the heel of your hand to push the dough away from you.
Initialize Gripper: Activate Gripper 1 to a 60-degree angle. Ensure Gripper 1’s force sensor reading is less than 2.5 Newtons. Maintain this state for 0.5 seconds.
Locate Dough Center: Using visual sensors (RGB camera with 640x480 resolution)

Approach DoughCenter: Move Gripper 1 towards the DoughCenter. Execute a linear motion. Target trajectory: Move from (0, 0, 100mm) to (0, 0, 95mm) over 1.0 seconds. Velocity: 50mm/s. Maintain a consistent trajectory.

Initiate Contact: At a distance of 30mm from DoughCenter (Z-axis), reduce Gripper 1 velocity to 10mm/s.  Activate force sensor. Wait for force sensor reading to exceed 1.0 Newtons. This indicates initial contact with the dough. Duration: 0.3 seconds.

Apply Push: Once contact is established, increase Gripper 1 velocity to 75mm/s. Execute a linear motion outwards, away from DoughCenter. Target trajectory: Move from (0, 0, 95mm) to (0, 0, 100mm) over 0.5 seconds. Maintain a consistent trajectory.  Force sensor reading should remain above 1.5 Newtons.

Maintain Push: Continue pushing the dough outward with Gripper 1 at 75mm/s for a duration of 2.0 seconds. Monitor force sensor reading to ensure consistent pressure.  Adjust velocity dynamically to maintain force between 1.5 and 2.0 Newtons. Record the total displacement (X-axis change) every 0.1 seconds.

Retract Gripper: After 2.0 seconds, reduce Gripper 1 velocity to 0mm/s over 0.3 seconds.  Allow Gripper 1 to return to its initial 60-degree angle position.  Force sensor reading should return to less than 2.5 Newtons within 0.5 seconds.
Rotate Dough: Rotate the dough 90 degrees and repeat the pushing and folding motion.
Robot arm initiates movement. Joint 1 (shoulder) extends to 65 degrees. Maintain a forward trajectory vector of 0.2 meters. Duration: 0.5 seconds. Verify positional accuracy within +/- 0.02 meters.

Robot arm joint 2 (elbow) rotates to -30 degrees. Maintain a relative angular velocity of 2 radians per second. Duration: 1 second. Confirm target rotation axis alignment with the center of the dough, verified by visual sensor data.

Robot arm joint 3 (wrist) rotates to -10 degrees. Apply a force of 0.5 Newtons. Duration: 0.3 seconds. Ensure wrist rotation axis is perpendicular to the dough surface, measured by tactile sensor data.

Robot arm extends to a position 15 centimeters above the center of the dough. Maintain a vertical height of 15 centimeters. Duration: 0.7 seconds. Position sensor data confirms location at the center of the dough.

Robot arm applies a rotational force of 1.2 Newtons to the dough. Maintain a rotational axis aligned with the vertical. Duration: 1.8 seconds. Monitor dough deformation using strain sensors; target deformation should be within +/- 0.05mm.

Robot arm retracts 5 centimeters. Joint 1 (shoulder) returns to 60 degrees. Joint 2 (elbow) returns to -25 degrees. Joint 3 (wrist) returns to -8 degrees. Duration: 1.5 seconds. Verify return to initial position within +/- 0.03 meters.

Repeat steps 1-5, but with the dough rotated 90 degrees clockwise. Adjust all joint angles and forces accordingly. Maintain a precise 90-degree angular rotation target. Confirm final rotation direction using visual markers.
Robot arm maintains a stationary position 2 centimeters above the dough’s center. Duration: 3 seconds. Monitor dough surface for visual confirmation of the pushing and folding motion via camera feed.
Continue Kneading: Repeat the pushing, folding, and rotating motion for the specified time (typically 8-10 minutes).

Initialize Arm Position: Extend Robotic Arm (Designation: Arm-A) to a forward position. Shoulder joint angle: 35 degrees. Elbow joint angle: 90 degrees. Wrist rotation: 0 degrees. Calculate and execute precise Cartesian coordinates for the tool tip (Designation: Tool-T) at X-axis: 0.00 meters, Y-axis: 0.15 meters, Z-axis: 0.05 meters. Verify Tool-T position using onboard visual sensor (Designation: Vis-1) and adjust as needed within a tolerance of +/- 0.001 meters.

Initiate Push Motion: Apply a force of 15 Newtons to Tool-T. Push Tool-T directly into the dough (Designation: Dough-1) in a straight line for a duration of 0.5 seconds. Maintain Tool-T trajectory perpendicular to the dough’s surface, as determined by Vis-1. Record Tool-T position data every 0.02 seconds.

Execute Fold Motion: After the push motion concludes, immediately rotate Arm-A clockwise by 90 degrees around the Z-axis. Rotation speed: 2 radians per second. Hold this rotation for 0.3 seconds. Simultaneously, apply a force of 10 Newtons to Tool-T, pushing the dough towards the right side (as viewed by Vis-1) for a duration of 1 second. Ensure the fold angle is approximately 45 degrees.
